Award.AwardTitle: Catalyst Project: Enhancing Undergraduate Research, Innovation and Education in Engineering and Computer Science – Integration of Smart Sensors Design to Citizens Science

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at Delaware State University satisfies the requirements of a catalyst project in that it promises to implement a novel approach to STEM education and research at the institution. Moreover, the project provides the PI with the opportunity to obtain preliminary results for the development of a research project that studies the impact of his interdisciplinary and inter-institutional/community approach for developing next-generation, undergraduate student researchers.

In this project, the PI proposes an undergraduate research, innovation and education, infusion program, connected with citizen’s science. The project promised to empower and prepare students at Delaware State University for the next-generation STEM workforce. This infusion program will bring together next-generation smart sensing technologies for environmental and human health, and advance manufacturing. These novel technologies are generally low-power, lightweight, portable and able to be deployed on ubiquitous platforms, including residential, urban or agricultural, and industrial locations. Several such technologies may include sensing and continuous monitoring of required physical, chemical or biological environments. These sensing systems when coupled with advanced manufacturing technologies, e.g. high-precision 3-D printing for human skin-electronic interface, or bio-compatible wearable sensors, can shift the paradigm of our interaction, and understanding of the outside world. The broader impacts of this project includes undergraduate research, education and DEL-AWARE Citizens Science program that will involve various stakeholders, including diverse participants from academia, local environmental agencies/organizations, community group of participants from academia, local environmental agencies/organizations, communities, schools, hospitals and health services in the State of Delaware.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project's major objective was to create an interdisciplinary program that would catalyze and accelerate education and research innovations between engineering physics and computer science students at Delaware State University. A project-based program embedded in the academic curriculum was the main driver for engaging and retaining students. To this end, several pilot projects were integrated directly with courses across the curriculum in Engineering Physics and Computer Science in the Division of Physics, Engineering, Mathematics, and Computer Science (PEMaCS). The projects included focus areas of sensor systems design, adaptive manufacturing, and Internet of Things (IoT) - relevant to environmental and human-health sensing.  Over the duration of this project, we engaged more than 50 undergraduate students from Engineering Physics and Computer Science with projects leading to laboratory prototypes and field deployments of sensor instruments. 

Major Outcome-1 (Enhancing research and education capacity at Delaware State University (DSU)): The project enabled new pathways of engaging students in team-based projects in engineering with applications in electrical/electronic design, bioengineering, and computer science. This was enabled by instrumentation and research capacity developed from these projects in areas of computational design (CAD and Printed Circuit Board Design software), and upgrades of mechanical 3-D printing and machining facility at DSU. 

Major Outcome-2(New Curriculum Design): Introduction of a project-based curriculum in Engineering Physics with connected courses in Signals and Systems, Analog Electronics, and Topics courses in Microcontroller programming. In the previous curriculum of Engineering Physics at DSU, there were no design engineering courses at the freshman level. This was a major source of the program’s retention rate and engagement of students for higher-level courses.  Pilot projects that were introduced from this grant funding resulted in two new recent courses (Introduction to Engineering) in the freshman curriculum. 

Major Outcome-3 (Undergraduate Summer Research Program): Intensive summer research program in Years 1,2 and 3 (one-year extension of the award) with training workshops in CAD design, LABVIEW, MATLAB, Python programming, and hands-on projects with Optical Sensor design and Solar Energy projects. The students in workshops presented their research during DSU’s Summer Research Symposium (2022, 2023 and 2024). 

Major Outcome-4 (Student-led Integrated Research Projects): This interdisciplinary team of students led field deployments of the three (laser-based mid-infrared sensing prototypes to measure environmental air quality and flux from various natural (environmental) sources. The prototypes for carbon dioxide, water vapor, and methane are also implemented for biomedical applications- e.g., to study methane or Carbon for exhaled breath analysis. The three prototype systems include (a) a laser-based carbon dioxide and water vapor sensor, (b) an automated miniature (hotwire) wind speed sensor integrated with a particulate monitor, and (c) synthesized software.

Major Outcome-5 (A Pathway to synthesizing environmental and health data from field sensors): Over the course of this project, we have shown that developing integrated technologies that unify environmental, and health applications is vital for society. Especially, in the state of Delaware with higher rates of asthma-related illness, and the State’s diverse economic activities leading to emissions from industrial, agricultural, and livestock operations- such environmental impacts on human health can be interconnected. A ubiquitous sensor network that can provide information on the environment correlated with health impacts will greatly influence many other disciplines and fields of engineering and technology. Therefore, combining methane, carbon dioxide, and Particulate matter sensing systems on stationary or mobile platforms with cities can bridge the gap between environmental and health data.

Major Outcome-6 (Enhancing research and education capacity at Delaware State University (DSU)): The project enabled new pathways of engaging students in team-based projects in engineering with applications in electrical/electronic design, bioengineering, and computer science. This was enabled by instrumentation and research capacity developed from these projects in areas of computational design (CAD and Printed Circuit Board Design software), and upgrades of mechanical 3-D printing and machining facility at DSU. 

Major Outcome-7 (Technical Presentations at SPIE Photonics West and CLEO conferences): The students involved in the project presented their work at the SPIE Annual Photonics West Conference and CLEO conference.

Finally, the grant enabled further research funding from NASA and NSF that will sustain several of the student engagement, research, and educational activities of the project. 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Mohammad A Khan
